fields.description:
On the upgrade of Fisheye 2.4.0, Perforce repositories fail to index or have odd behavior indexing.  Symptoms of this problem include:

* Only some content being indexed and viewable in the repository source.
* No content at all being indexed, and source repository shows no files in the UI.
* Files are shown in the repository UI but they are all listed as deleted.

Common errors in the log files include:

{noformat}
2010-10-21 14:59:29,001 ERROR [IncrementalPinger1] fisheye.app P4Cache-getFileRevision - Could not determine revid for key project1/main/README.txt@2
2010-10-21 14:59:29,001 ERROR [IncrementalPinger1] fisheye.app P4Cache-getFileRevision - Could not determine revid for key project1/main/TEST.txt@2
{noformat}

After development investigation it appears that this is related to case-sensitivity issues as part of the 2.4.0 release.
fields.summary: Perforce case-sensitivity issues on FE 2.4 Upgrade

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in FishEye's revision ID parameters on annotated views. This affects FishEye 2.3.0 to 2.3.6 inclusive.

* An attacker might take advantage of an XSS vulnerability to steal the current session of a logged-in user.
* XSS vulnerabilities potentially allow an attacker to embed their own JavaScript into a FishEye page. An attacker's text and script might be displayed to other people viewing the page.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/uwJrDQ

You can read more about XSS attacks at cgisecurity, CERT and other places on the web:
* http://www.cgisecurity.com/xss-faq.html
* http://www.cert.org/advisories/CA-2000-02.html
fields.summary: XSS vulnerability in FishEye's Revision ID Parameters (Annotated Views)

fields.description:
Clearcase needs to use UNC paths for the view storage directory, if you don't use it, you get the following error.

{noformat}2010-02-19 23:58:55,149 WARN  [InitialPinger1] fisheye.app com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseContext-handleProcessError - 
Error executing command (cleartool mkview -snapshot -tag fisheye -vws d:\path\toviews\fisheye.vws d:\path\toviews\fisheye.vws ) : 
Non-zero exit code: 1 cleartool: Error: storage directory must be in UNC style (e.g. \\host\share\...){noformat} 

* http://www.ipnom.com/ClearCase-Commands/mkview.html
{quote}-vws
    Specifies the location for the snapshot view storage directory. On Windows systems, this must be a UNC name.
    For information on using this option to create snapshot views for disconnected use, see the section, "Disconnected Use of Snapshot Views".
    We recommend that you use -stgloc rather than this option whenever possible.{quote}

We should probably validate the input better.
fields.summary: Clearcase on Windows: Document & validate that is given UNC paths for the view storage directory

fields.description:
If you sever the connection between Fisheye and a remote Git repository, it won't reconnect until the repository is manually restarted.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Add a new remote Git repo to Fisheye, allow it to index.
2. Stop the remote Git repo.
3. Allow the poller to run and throw a connection issue.
4. Restart the remote Git repo.
5. Notice that Fisheye doesn't reconnect the repository.

fields.description:
When FishEye scans ClearCase for changes, it only requests the changes since the last scan date/time. After the scan completes, FishEye records that it has scanned all changes up to the current time. There are a number of issues for which I will create Jiras. The 'lastScannedDateTime' that is recorded is the time on the FishEye server when the scan completed.

* The lastScannedDateTime is not the time that the ClearCase was last queried. So if there are a lot of changes and indexing took some time, any commits performed during indexing will be missed (completely).
* The date/time string that is used does not contain any timezone details, so if the ClearCase server and the FishEye server are in different timezones, bad things will happen.
* The lastScannedDateTime that is recorded is based on the local server time on the FishEye server. If the ClearCase and FishEye servers aren't in synch, some commits will be indexed multiple times or not at all.

The fix is to record the date/time of the last seen change as the lastScannedDateTime. This time is based on the ClearCase servers time.
fields.summary: ClearCase indexing misses revisions or indexes revisions multiple times if the server clocks of the ClearCase server and the FishEye servers are out of synch or in different timezones

fields.description:
Limiting Fisheye content in a Crucible project does not seem to have any effect on the Activity Stream or statistics in a project view.  Reindexing the repository or Crucible data doesn't seem to have any effect.

To reproduce:

1. Create a new repository in Fisheye.
2. Associate said repository with a Crucible project.
3. Under {{Projects -> Fisheye Content ->}} add a new path for the repository content.  For example, only include {{/tags}}.
4. View the Project URL (http://<host>:8060/project/<project_key>)

You will observe that the project isn't restricting the Activity Streams or statistics based on the path provided, it will still include all activity from the FE repository.

fields.description:
When you add a file to a directory in ClearCase, CC creates two file revisions:

# rev 1 - the initial contents of the file.

This causes weirdness in Crucible; you can have multiple revisions of a single file in a single change set.
fields.summary: ClearCase empty revision 0s are causing problems for Crucible. Need to reconsider handling of empty 0 revs during indexing.

fields.description:
ClearCase does have support for moving and renaming files, but FishEye doesn't pick up the changes. 

In ClearCase when you move a file, it moves the whole version tree and lshistory will show only the new file location. There is no new version created in the file revision tree, so there the whole move is missed by FishEye. FishEye does process directory diffs in order to detect deletions and will create a deleted revision for the 'moved from' path.

This shortcoming results in a number of symptoms:
* When a file is moved, FishEye marks it as deleted, but does not create an 'added' revision for the file. The moved file will 'disappear' until a change is made to the file.
* When a file is moved and replaced in a single commit (of the parent directory), an parent-of link will be incorrectly set up between the two revisions at the old path.

There is a way to find the new location however. A file revisions objectId will stay the same and we can get the new path from CC by using the objectId. So the way to go would be:

# detect directory modification event when the contents have changed. This can be fairly complex, because we need to deal with all sorts of scenarios: file A being moved and a new file A being added as a replacement.
# if the directory has changed, and a file has been removed, get the objectId from the latest fileRevision that we've got. Get the new path from CC by using the objectId.
# create 2 new file revisions:
## a delete revision for the old location (if needed?)
## a moved revision for the new location with the appropriate ancestor links 

Moves / renames are actually returned by cleartool diff -pre -ser for directory revisions. We're already getting the data in the {{ClearCaseDirectoryDiffParser}}, but we're currently only looking for deletes.
fields.summary: ClearCase support for moving and renaming files is lacking

fields.description:
When a branch is locked in ClearCase, the output of {{cleartool lstype -short -type brtype}} returns {{branch_name (locked)}}. 

For locked branches, this is displayed as the branch name in the branch includes/excludes dropdowns in the admin pages.

During indexing, the selected include/exclude branch name does not match the actual branch name and the include/exclude logic breaks down.

For now a workaround is to manually edit the config.xml file and remove the " (locked)" part from the branch name.
fields.summary: ClearCase: locked branches cause aren't correctly processed in branch includes/excludes

fields.description:
When a branch is excluded, FE won't be able to set up the ancestor links correctly between a file revision on an included branch that is branched from an excluded branch. As a result, the linecount for the \0 version on the included branch will be 0 and the blame for the lines in the original file will be missing.

The fix is to treat the \0 as an addition and get the file contents from cleartool to determine the correct number of lines.
fields.summary: ClearCase: Blame and linecount are wrong when parent of a filerevision is excluded because of branch exclusions.

fields.description:
The foundation baseline for a branch is never indexed, thus only changes show up in FishEye.

Solution: Index the activities in the baseline as though they are part of the branch being indexed. Set their HEADness appropriately. 

If the same FileRevs are then detected for another branch indexed later on, check the "created on" is correct and set HEAD (as per CRUC-4418)
fields.summary: UCM Clearcase: foundation baselines are not indexed

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In FishEye, if you have a branch in Mercurial containing a newline, indexing will fail.

with some new lines"{noformat}

{noformat}

fields.description:
If a PVOB there has no elements (and therefore there aren't any element type definitions) then Fisheye will throw an error.  This happens if element type definitions are stored at the UCM component's VOBs.

FishEye should use "cleartool descr -s vob:path/to/file.cpp" to determine the correct VOB of each file.  Instead FishEye always uses the project's PVOB to do queries.

As a temporary workaround the ClearCase admin can create the missing element type definitions within project_pvob.
fields.summary: ClearCase administrative VOB hierarchy uses wrong VOBs for queries

fields.description:
If you specify a an Exclude pattern that matches content in a Git repository, upon reindex of that repository the indexing process will fail.

First, you will get a message in the logs saying that the content isn't being watched:

fields.description:
On the ClearCase admin screen, you can specify include/exclude rules for VOBs or UCM projects. You can use a comma separated list of patterns. Each pattern is either a plain string or a regular expression.

There are multiple issues:

* the patterns aren't trimmed, so using a comma followed by a space will result in strings not being matched.
* when using a plain string, it is currently testing whether the string is part of the VOB/UCM project pattern. For example, the pattern '/vobs/myvob' not only matches {{vob:/vobs/myvob}}, but also {{vob:/vobs/myvob2}}.
* the strings being matched are the VOB/UCM Project name prefixed by 'vob:' of 'project:'. The use of the prefix is a bit awkward when specifying inclusion/exclusion rules

suggestions:
# {{trim()}}
# Use exact matching on the full path of the vob/project, with vob:/project: prefix removed on both sides, so it is optional in the UI
fields.summary: ClearCase include/exclude rules do unexpected things

fields.description: e.g. if I am hitting the URL http://localhost:6060/foo/admin/admin.do#repositories-view-FE and then restart the server, I am no longer loggged in as an admin. fields.description:
The code in {{ActivityStreamHandler.searchFromChangeset()}} (https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/browse/FE-hg/src/java/com/atlassian/fisheye/activity/ActivityStreamHandler.java?r=48830dd#to870 - used by findPrev/Next only) copes very badly with search errors (resulting in this: https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/ADM-9656).

I'll add comments to describe what it's doing - it is really looking for the current changeset in the stream then finding the next one. it should never adjust it's start time (as then it will NEVER find it's current changeset), instead, widen its window and if it finds results beyond the time of the current changeset without finding the current changeset, it knows something is wrong (rather than iterating over EVERY changeset in that direction), like http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-4097?focusedCommentId=208843&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-208843.

fields.description:
* If a file is {{hg rm file}} and then {{hg cp other file}}, the diff just shows a modification (to the same named file), but the meta information in hgfelog.py says it is a copy and the parent rev is the rev id of the parent where it was copied from - so:
*# That revision of the named file may not exist (as it is actually a rev of the copy source)
*# If we use the copy source, we don't have the right diffs to properly calculate the LOC.

* If there was no revision of the copy target in the parent commit, (i.e. a copy over something that was deleted a while ago), the diff will work properly, diffing to the copy source and we can use that as the predecessor/ancestor.
fields.summary: HG: Cope with copies over deleted files

fields.description: The Unicode character fix that was implemented as part of CRUC-4793 causes ExternalProcess to fail for commandline arguments with spaces in them. Because the shell now expands the command-line arguments, arguments with spaces in them are no longer recognised as a single argument by the external process that is being spawned.
fields.summary: ExternalProcess fails on Windows with commandline arguments with spaces.

fields.description:
This is the git version of CRUC-3408.

Git has different issues, as it has no concept of a changeset being committed to a particular branch, so it is harder to detect branch states (created, open, closed, inactive).
fields.summary: GIT: HEAD-ness of FileRevs is incorrect for branches

fields.description:
CommonRevInfoDAO.updateBranchHead() sets what revisions of a file it thinks is the head on a specified branch, updating the CommonSchema.E_HEAD_IN_ANY_BRANCH_REVIDS and CommonSchema.E_HEAD_IN_BRANCH_TO_REVID indices.

Write tests for hg:

multiple heads: a file can have two head-like file revs on a branch - both must be cleaned up on a merge

branch creation: A filerev can be a head on a new branch, but its ancestor is still a head on another branch. On branch creation, (CRUC-3809) files that are part of that branch manifest may not be head-like - so branch creation needs to be detected and all file revs in the manifest marked as head-like.

branch merge/close: All filerevs in the closed branch need to be made non head-like

branch reopen: All filerevs in the branch need to be made head-like

Focus on hg, but create new JIRA's for git(CRUC-3812)/p4/cc where we detect they will have problems.
fields.summary: HG: Set Head flags correctly for merges/branch creation.

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in FishEye's Code Metrics Report plugin. This affects FishEye 2.0.x to 2.3.6 inclusive.

* An attacker might take advantage of an XSS vulnerability to steal the current session of a logged-in user.
* XSS vulnerabilities potentially allow an attacker to embed their own JavaScript into a FishEye page. An attacker's text and script might be displayed to other people viewing the page.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/FishEye+Security+Advisory+2010-10-20

You can read more about XSS attacks at cgisecurity, CERT and other places on the web:
* http://www.cgisecurity.com/xss-faq.html
* http://www.cert.org/advisories/CA-2000-02.html
fields.summary: XSS vulnerability in FishEye's Code Metrics Report plugin

fields.description:
The current implementation is using the cleartool command:

{code}lsstream "%[dstreams]CXp" streamname{code}

which returns the development streams for a stream. If the command results in an empty list, it is assumed to be a dev stream.

This command does not correctly detect whether a stream is an integration stream. You can have an integration stream without any dependent development streams. A better test is to do a cleartool describe of the stream. This returns whether a stream is an integration stream or a development stream.
fields.summary: ClearCase detection of whether a stream is an integration stream fails when there are no development streams

fields.description:
When FishEye indexes a Git repository, the git commands that are used return a content hash for the file (e.g. to refer to the parent(s) of a file, or when getting the manifest at the head of a branch). Fisheye uses this content hash to find the matching file revision, but matches on the content hash only. This is insufficient, because (versions of) different files can have the same contents and therefore the same hashcode. 

The result is that in these cases too many file revisions are being marked as being 'head' on a branch, tagged. Or in the case of finding the parent revision, the wrong revision could be chosen.

An example of this is FE-2725. Here, a directory is moved, but the content-hashes of the files don't change. When determining which revisions are head on branch, all revisions with the content-hash are marked as head and as a result both the old and the new directory shows up as being active.
fields.summary: Git: Use of file content-hash to map to file revision is insufficient

fields.description:
When you specify VOB or UCM Project include and/or include rules for a ClearCase repository, the config.xml that is generated does not comply with the schema. According to the schema, the following is allowed:

{noformat}
...
<vobRules>
   <vobToProcess>vob:/vob/myvob</vobToProcess>
</vobRules>
...
{noformat}

or 

{noformat}
<vobRules>
   <vobIncludes>/vob/myvob,/vob/anothervob</vobIncludes>
   <vobExcludes></vobExcludes>
</vobRules>
{noformat}

Instead, the FishEye administation creates the following XML:

{noformat}
<vobRules>
   <vobToProcess>All</vobToProcess>
   <vobIncludes>/vob/myvob,/vob/anothervob</vobIncludes>
   <vobExcludes></vobExcludes>
</vobRules>
{noformat}

A workaround until this is resolved is to manually remove the {{<vobToProcess>All</vobToProcess>}} part from the config.xml
fields.summary: ClearCase: specifying include or exclude rules for projects and vobs results in an invalid config.xml file, causing errors on restart

fields.description:
(This is a modification to the original issue, which was unrelated to the issue the customer was having: The original issue has been recreated as CRUC-5237).

When a file is copied over an existing file using SCM commands (possible in git/hg/p4/svn) and the scm reports this to us, we (as of 2.4) nominate the copy source as the ancestor of the FileRevision. This means it inherits the blame of the copy source (correctly), but also, when a review is created, it uses the copy source as the default "diff parent".

In addition, another change was made in 2.4 to prefer ancestors over predecessors when considering whether a revision being added to a review - if a FileRevision has ancestors, it only checks those. Thus, adding a new revision copied over an old one after adding the old one will not get it to match the revision graph, causing the review to have 2 of the same path, one being a diff to the previous and one being a diff to the copy source, when what is really desired is a single FRX with 3 revisions in a row.

Given a revision graph like:
{code} C = Copy, P = PRedecessor, M = Modification

    3 --P-- 4
   /       /
  C       C
 /       /
1 --M-- 2
{code}

I see 2 possible solutions to this problem:

# Reconsider the diff parent when we have a copy over an existing file - instead of choosing the copy source, use the predecessor - if the predecessor was deleted (no file existed at the path), we should use the copy source. To implement this, we would also have to change the behaviour of the ancestor/predecessor detection
# Change the ancestor/predecessor detection to consider predecessors as well. This would allow the user to either:
## Add the 3 revision (and implicitly rev 1), then select the rev 4 - this would then add them as a single path 1-3-4
## Add rev 4, then edit the review and remove the implicitly selected rev 2, then add 3 (implicitly adding 1, resulting in 1-3-4
fields.summary: Fix diff parent/ancestry detection for reviews where there is a copy over an existing file

fields.description:
When the connection is lost to the ClearCase license or VOB server, the cleartool command reports the connection error, but FishEye doesn't pause the repository.

As a result, all the following cleartool commands fail as well, but eat up a lot of CPU cycles.
fields.summary: ClearCase: FE maxes out CPU when the connection to the ClearCase server is lost

fields.description:
The VOB that is shown in 'VOB to include' in the admin screen is wrong.

Probably, the value isn't being set properly when loading an existing configuration. 

Issue was reported by mail by a 2.4 pre-release customer
fields.summary: ClearCase GWT admin: editing a repo config changes the 'VOB to include'
Text files are seen as binary

fields.description: When a tag is deleted in Git, FishEye doesn't pick it up. We've already added support for this for Hg; we could probably reuse this pattern for Git.
fields.summary: Deleted tags in Git are not removed from the FishEye index

fields.description:
Currently, the git style diff detects one of the files in binary and produces a binary patch, which we interpret to mean the current rev is binary - probably need to look at the file contents instead.

In addition, this causes the line count to be wrong - the text version of the file will have a line count of 0, and all subsequent mods will add/remove from that.
fields.summary: HG: Correctly detect when a file moves from binary -> text

fields.description:
# In hgfelog.py, the MetaChange detection is too simplistic: a duplicate modification on a second branch shows up as a MetaChange because the file rev on the other branch is re-used. hgsubversion and hgconvert both produce commits from svn merges that have filerevs whose linkrev is not the current commit.
# In FishEye, we create a new revision, but it's parent rev is the last content change revsions parent, instead of the last content change revision, because that's what mercurial stores in it's filectx. We'd have to detect that and cope with it.
# In FE, a subsequent content mod will also have as it's parent the previous content mod revision, instead of the perm change revision, again, because that's what mercurial stores.
fields.summary: HG: Cope with MetaChanges (permission changes)

fields.description:
The Git version of CRUC-3366.

Change the indexing to show the parents of a merge commit for the file(s) and add them to the FileRevision.
fields.summary: GIT: Slurp and index mutiple file parents for FileRevision

fields.description:
For deliver operations: when integration stream is indexed first, delivered FileRevs get created and marked as HEAD on integration stream and when we index the dev stream(s), the FileRev already exists so it is skipped.

It should check that the "created on branch" is set correctly to the real originator and set the HEADness appropriately.
fields.summary: UCM ClearCase:File revisions first indexed on the integration stream are ignored on development stream

fields.description:
Commits which are out of time order, as in rebased or histeditted commits, will be shown in the LoC charts against the day the commit says they were done.

This means they will be out of order compared to the commit graph.

To fix, we probably need to introduce a fisheye-internal date which forces linearity (ie parents commits are always older than their children).
fields.summary: HG: Non-linear cs dates in DVCS screw up LoC

fields.description:
edit Repository -> SCM Details
Update the URL
Test connection updated url is ignored... test fails
save and connection now works
fields.summary: Fisheye Repository editor - test connection doesn't take into account changes to location

fields.summary: Invocation of git blame fails for files that contain spaces

fields.description:
When a timeout occurs in the CleartoolInteractiveProcess, a ProcessException is thrown. This is then caught and logged, after which the scanner resumes as if nothing happened. 

In case of a timeout, the handler should be marked as not having succeeded to ensure that the scanner is aware of the failure.
fields.summary: ClearCase interactive process logs timeout and forgets it has failed

fields.description:
Code Metrics Plugin

Change the separate {code}No author blame found for FE-light/ - has the repository finished indexing?{code} and {code}No LOC data (by extension) found at FE-hg/ - has the repository finished indexing?{code} messages to a single message shown for either both situation:
{code}This plugin does not have access to all the repository data.
Some data is not available: The repository may be indexing, may not support LoC or has "stored Diffs" turned off{code}
fields.summary: LoC: Fix UI for Code Metrics Plugin

fields.description:
The DVCS content indexing simply indexes the latest modified revision of a path that was modified during a batch. It doesn't check the latest modified rev on the "main" branch and doesn't filter out the ones that were only changed on branches.

Also see: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-2596 (The branch that we index content for should be configurable)
fields.summary: DVCS: Content indexing indexes latest rev of a file on whatever branch was latest

fields.description:
A cleartool error occurs when we run a diff on revision 0 of a file with its predecessor, because rev 0 doesn't have a predecessor.

There is a twist however; when you create a branch, you also get revision 0s for all the files that are in the branch. In this case they are not empty and presumably(?) have a predecessor.
fields.summary: ClearCase diffs between rev 0 and predecessor fail in error

fields.description: Labels are indexed only when a file revision is indexed. Labels that are applied to file revisions that has already been indexed by FishEye won't show up at all.
fields.summary: ClearCase: FE doesn't pick up labels after the revisions have been indexed initially
